message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest meningococcal meningitis, which requires immediate treatment with antibiotics. Ceftriaxone and vancomycin are commonly used to treat meningococcal meningitis. Rifampin is used for prophylaxis of close contacts. Ampicillin and ciprofloxacin are not first-line treatments for this infection. Option B includes doxycycline, which is not recommended for use in children under the age of 8. Option C includes rifampin prophylaxis but does not include an appropriate antibiotic for treatment of meningococcal meningitis. Therefore, option D is the most appropriate next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest meningococcemia, and the CSF analysis confirms meningitis. Ceftriaxone and vancomycin therapy are recommended for the patient, along with rifampin prophylaxis for close contacts. Ampicillin and ciprofloxacin are not appropriate for this condition. Doxycycline and rifampin are sometimes used for prophylaxis, but should not be given together as they can interact and reduce effectiveness. Vancomycin and rifampin are not sufficient therapy for meningococcal meningitis.

We refer to the UpToDate article on "Management of Meningococcal Disease in Children" for help. The patient's symptoms, including fever, irritability, and purple spots, along with CSF analysis showing abundant neutrophils and decreased glucose, indicate meningococcal meningitis. Ceftriaxone and vancomycin are appropriate antibiotics to treat the patient, while rifampin prophylaxis for close contacts is recommended. Option A is incorrect because ciprofloxacin is not recommended for prophylaxis in children. Option B is incorrect because doxycycline is not recommended for prophylaxis in children under 8 years old. Option C is incorrect because rifampin should not be used as monotherapy for treatment or prophylaxis of meningococcal disease.

Among the options, only ceftriaxone and vancomycin therapy can treat bacterial meningitis. Rifampin prophylaxis is also needed for close contacts. Ampicillin/ciprofloxacin and cefotaxime/doxycycline are not the first-line treatments for bacterial meningitis. Vancomycin/rifampin is not enough to treat bacterial meningitis.

Among the options, ceftriaxone and vancomycin is the recommended initial therapy for bacterial meningitis in infants and children. Rifampin is used for prophylaxis of close contacts. Ampicillin and ciprofloxacin are not the recommended therapy for bacterial meningitis in infants and children. Vancomycin and rifampin are not sufficient for initial therapy for bacterial meningitis. Doxycycline is not recommended for prophylaxis in children.

Among the options, ceftriaxone and vancomycin therapy for the patient and rifampin prophylaxis for close contacts are the most appropriate next step in management. Ampicillin is used for Listeria monocytogenes meningitis but is not necessary for this case. Ciprofloxacin and doxycycline are not recommended for children under 8, and vancomycin and rifampin are better choices than doxycycline for prophylaxis.

CSF analysis also supports the diagnosis. The most appropriate next step in management is to start treatment with ceftriaxone and vancomycin for the patient and rifampin prophylaxis for close contacts. This combination of antibiotics provides a broad-spectrum coverage against the bacteria and rifampin is used for prophylaxis in close contacts to prevent the spread of infection. The purple spots on the trunk and extremities suggest petechiae, which points to a possible diagnosis of meningococcal meningitis. The most appropriate next step in management would be to start ceftriaxone and vancomycin therapy for the patient and rifampin prophylaxis for close contacts. Ampicillin and ciprofloxacin are not effective against meningococcal meningitis, and doxycycline is not recommended in children under 8 years old. We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the purple spots, decreased glucose concentration in CSF, and the high leukocyte count suggest a bacterial infection, most likely meningococcemia. The most appropriate next step in management is to start therapy with ceftriaxone and vancomycin for the patient and rifampin prophylaxis for close contacts. This regimen covers both Neisseria meningitidis and Streptococcus pneumoniae, the most common bacterial causes of meningitis in children. Ampicillin and ciprofloxacin only cover some strains of N. meningitidis, while doxycycline is not recommended for use in children under 8 years old. Vancomycin alone does not cover N. meningitidis, and rifampin alone is not effective against established meningitis.
